title: Eating forbidden fat unknowingly
vignette: Someone eats a dish later discovered to contain forbidden chelev.

options.text: Bring a sin-offering when informed.
No offering since it was accidental.

title: Doubtful transgression
vignette: Uncertain if he ate chelev or permissible fat, the person is troubled.

options.text: Offer a provisional guilt-offering just in case.
Wait for clarity before bringing anything.

title: Too poor for required offering
vignette: A sinner cannot afford even the minimal bird offering.

options.text: Allow delay until means are found.
He must beg or borrow to bring it promptly.

title: Unaware impurity in central complex
vignette: Someone entered the central complex while impure without realizing until later.

options.text: Bring a sin-offering once he knows.
No need; ignorance excuses him.

title: Mistaken eating on Yom Kippur
vignette: Believing the fast began later, a man ate after sunset.

options.text: He must bring a sin-offering.
Since he miscalculated, apology suffices.

title: Multiple sins in one lapse
vignette: Eating chelev and blood together might incur separate penalties.

options.text: Bring offerings for each prohibition.
One offering covers the whole meal.

title: Delaying offering after knowledge
vignette: He admits his sin but postpones bringing the offering for months.

options.text: Delay is wrong; bring it immediately.
He may wait until convenient.

title: Intentional sin then repentance
vignette: A person purposely ate blood but later regrets deeply.

options.text: Bring the offering even though intentional.
Repentance alone suffices without offering.

title: Unsure which sin was committed
vignette: He knows he violated either chelev or blood but not which one.

options.text: Bring a single provisional offering.
Avoid offering until certainty is achieved.

title: Conversion after sin
vignette: A outsider ate chelev and then converted to Judaism.

options.text: No offering; the sin predates conversion.
He must still bring a offering now.

title: Different rules for men and women
vignette: Question arises if women bring the same offerings for certain sins.

options.text: Yes, obligations are equal.
Women are exempt from some offerings.

title: Partial confession of sin
vignette: A sinner admits eating chelev but conceals also eating blood.

options.text: He must confess fully for atonement.
Bring one offering and keep the rest private.

title: Expired guilt-offering money
vignette: Funds set aside for his offering were lost until after the year ended.

options.text: Use them anyway whenever found.
Consider them invalid and set aside new funds.

title: Borrowed animal for sin-offering
vignette: He borrows a friend’s goat for the offering but the friend disapproves later.

options.text: Offering still counts; intent was proper.
It fails; must use his own property.

title: Agent commits sin on behalf of another
vignette: A messenger mistakenly eats sacred fat while following someone else’s instructions.

options.text: The principal bears responsibility and brings the offering.
The messenger must bring the offering personally.
